awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Subduction below extreme sedimentation - A multidisciplinary transect from the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta to the IndoBurma Backarc
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves a study of a poorly understood and unique geologic setting: a subduction zone that has an exceptionally large amount of sediment, the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta (GBD).   The GBD is the world's most extreme example of sediment accretion, with sediments up to 19 km thick in the Bengal Basin. The region has little volcanism compared to other subduction zones and a large seismic risk; recent GPS results indicate that this highly oblique plate boundary is locked with the potential for a M8.2 earthquake that could affect more than 140 million people.  The project is motivated by the question of how the extreme sedimentation affects subduction phenomena. The project will involve a multi-institution, multi-nation collaboration involving scientists from Bangladesh, India and Myanmar, Singapore, Norway, and the U.S.

The PIs will focus on three major issues: 1) Neogene growth of the accretionary prism and earthquake hazard; 2) Crustal shortening and deformation across the IndoBurma Ranges and Burma Basin; and 3) Incoming fluid content and volcanism. To address these issues, they will deploy seismic, GPS, magnetotellurics and gravity sensors in a transect from the deformation front to the backarc in the Bangladesh-India-Myanmar Array (BIMA). Structural geology, geochemistry and thermochronology will provide additional constraints. They will use a broad program of numerical and laboratory modeling to integrate and interpret the results from the multiple data sets. This end-member case of extreme sediment subduction has broad implications for understanding these issues at all subduction zones.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project involves a study of a poorly understood and unique geologic setting: a subduction zone that has an exceptionally large amount of sediment, the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta. The Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta is the world's most extreme example of sediment accretion, with sediments up to 19 km thick in the Bengal Basin. The region has little volcanism compared to other subduction zones and a large seismic risk; recent GPS results indicate that this highly oblique plate boundary is locked with the potential for a M8.2 earthquake that could affect more than 140 million people. The project is motivated by the question of how the extreme sedimentation affects subduction phenomena. The project involves a multi-institution, multi-nation collaboration involving scientists from Bangladesh, India, Myanmar, Germany, Singapore, Norway, and the U.S.

The project aims to image the subsurface geology across the Indo-Burma subduction region from the sedimentary basins to the uppermost mantle. Knowledge of the present-day crustal structure will feed geochemical analysis, numerical modeling, and structural interpretations to better understand and develop a more consistent framework for the region's geological evolution. To address these issues, the PIs installed seismic and GPS sensors along the Bangladesh-India-Myanmar Array (BIMA); 31 seismic stations were installed in Myanmar and 29 in Bangladesh. To image the subsurface geology, we carried out several studies that used the recordings of large, distant earthquakes. After travelling deep within the Earth, the seismic waves from these earthquakes can be converted to other phases as they travel through the crust near our seismic stations. We focused on identifying four layers beneath the Bengal basin using a newly developed method that combines the conversions with reflections from different geological interfaces. We identify these features and use their timing to map the depth and seismic velocities of different layers. Information on the layers is used to build a three-dimensional model of the subsurface geology. We were able to map three distinct layers of sedimentary rocks that average 16.5 km in total thickness. The thick sedimentary package overlies crystalline crust that is similar in thickness and seismic velocity to continental crust.

This project provided research opportunities to two postdoctoral researchers and two graduate students. The PI and one graduate student were involved in installing the seismic stations in Myanmar. Each project participant took part in a multi-disciplinary project with international collaboration. Project results were presented in public talks and geoscientific presentations on extreme sediment subduction at international meetings and are being disseminated via peer-reviewed publications. The dataset has been archived shared with other interested researchers.
